claim: Either the apple is red or green. It is red. So not green

supporting.text: The claim follows the logical principle of the excluded middle, where an apple's color can only be one of the two given options (red or green) at a time.

attacks.text: The claim follows the logical principle of the excluded middle, where an apple's color can only be one of the two given options (red or green) at a time.
The principle of the excluded middle assumes binary color classification, but apples can have mixed colors (e.g., partially red and green).
Mixed-color apples are rare exceptions, and the principle still holds for the vast majority of cases where an apple is predominantly one color.
Color perception is subjective, and some individuals (e.g., colorblind people) may not distinguish between red and green clearly.
Standard color definitions and common perception still classify apples as red or green in most practical contexts, regardless of individual variations.

supporting.text: If the apple is confirmed to be red, it cannot simultaneously be green, as the two colors are mutually exclusive for a single apple.

attacks.text: If the apple is confirmed to be red, it cannot simultaneously be green, as the two colors are mutually exclusive for a single apple.
Some apples can exhibit both red and green patches (e.g., bi-colored varieties like Fuji or Gala), making them partially red and partially green.
The claim specifies a binary choice ('either red or green'), implying full coverage of the apple's surface by one color, excluding bi-colored cases.
Color perception is subjective; lighting conditions or color blindness could lead someone to misidentify a green apple as red.
Standard color definitions and controlled observation conditions resolve ambiguity, ensuring reliable identification of red vs. green.

attacks.text: The statement 'It is red' directly negates the possibility of the apple being green, as the two colors are distinct and non-overlapping.
